In the present research project, it was studied in detail how the incorporation of different precursor compounds and the supplementary addition of amounts of nickel in the MoS2 slabs can influence the structural and catalytic properties of trimetallic CoNiMo catalysts supported on SBA-15 mesoporous support with precise control of the amount and nature of the promoters. The catalysts were prepared by the incipient impregnation method using ammonium heptamolybdate and cobalt and nickel acetate, and nitrate as precursors adding nickel in molar amounts (5, 10, and 20%) of the cobalt atomic loading. Adding the Ni in small amounts allows us to keep the (Co + Ni)/(Co+Ni+Mo) molar ratio near 0.3. The catalysts formed were labeled according to the precursor compounds used (CoNixMo-Ac for acetates and CoNixMo-N for nitrates), where x is the percentage of nickel. Catalysts were then characterized by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, X-ray diffraction, high-resolution transmission electron microscopy, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. Catalysts were tested in the HDS of dibenzothiophene (DBT). Results show a significant impact of adding small amounts of nickel and the type of precursor compounds used for the CoNiMo trimetallic catalysts on the final HDS activity. In the case of the catalysts prepared with cobalt and nickel acetates, it was observed that the initial reaction rate values increased as the amount of Ni increased, being the CoNi5Mo-Ac, the catalyst with the lower catalytic activity. Increasing the amount of Ni causes an increase in the HDS of DBT. In the case of the catalysts prepared with nitrates, it could be observed a similar effect. The catalyst with the higher catalytic activity in both series was the CoNi20Mo-Ac. These results agree with the TEM analysis in which a decrease in the slab length of the MoS2 could be regarded as the de Ni amount increase. This means that the type of precursor used has an essential effect on the catalysts since modify their properties and catalytic activity and suggests that the materials synthesized with acetate precursors can help to improve the intrinsic activity of the HDS sites. Introduction Today there is a growing and worldwide concern about the protection of the environment. In these terms, it refers to energy for transportation (land, marine, and air) which are fuels that mostly come from petroleum, which upon combustion, generates compounds that are highly harmful to the environment. The negative impact on the environment caused by the combustion of fossil fuels is a major global concern. In addition to global temperature increase due to the emission of CO2, the emissions of toxic particles and gasses such as NOx and SOx also have drastic consequences on air quality, human health, and the preservation of the environment. This impact is reflected in the increase of stricter environmental standards for sulfur content, giving rise to the need to produce fuels with ultra-low sulfur content, with less than 10 ppm [1,2]. Deep hydrodesulfurization (HDS) is the most important industrial process used to satisfy the environmental requirements related to the sulfur content in petroleum-derived diesel fuel [2,3].Therefore, in most countries, governments implement or make more drastic regulations, such as regulations for sulfur in land transportation fuel. Regulations on sulfur in maritime transport fuel are also being implemented. To meet the very restrictive regulation demands, a challenge is developing catalysts with improved activity, controlled selectivity to desired products, and stronger resistance to poisons [4,5]. Among the factors that influence the activity and selectivity of a catalyst is the mode of preparation, the nature of the support, and the precursor used in the preparation of the active phases, to mention a few [6–11]. It is important to choose the precursor salt because it determines the salt´s solubility and ability to break down during calcination. The precursor salt is the option of the counterions and ligands that go with the catalytic element. The precursor must completely change into oxide states without producing side species that could alter the support´s characteristics. Usually, bimetallic catalysts whose active phase is a mixed transition metal sulfide (TMS) phase prepared from molybdenum (Mo) or tungsten (W), promoted by cobalt (Co) or nickel (Ni), and supported on alumina, are used in industry for the elimination of refractory sulfur-containing molecules [12,13]. However, despite significant advances in the modifications made to conventional catalysts, they are not sufficiently active and selective to cope with the future demands placed on fuels in terms of sulfur content [14]. Moreover, considering that crude oil tends to become heavier and heavier, which means that molecules containing heteroatoms (sulfur, nitrogen, oxygen, and metals) are becoming larger and, therefore, more refractory, there is a growing interest in the development of a new generation of catalysts, which should exhibit improved properties in the HDS process. Nowadays, research into hydrotreating ternary Co(Ni)MoW sulfide catalysts has become more attractive based on previously reported DFT calculations showing that the trimetallic active phase should be a better option than the bimetallic NiMoS and NiWS counterparts [15]. Therefore, the trimetallic catalysts should be able to supply the needed levels of hydrodesulfurization and optimum resistance to sulfur-containing compounds. In addition, using simultaneous Co and Ni atoms as promoters in the preparation of catalysts resulted in synergetic improving the fulfillment of trimetallic-supported catalysts [16–19]. Lately, our research group [20] reported employing Ni as a second promoter in the synthesis of trimetallic CoNiMoS catalysts supported on Al2O3, illustrated to be catalytically more active than a bimetallic CoMo catalyst in the reaction of HDS of DBT. Mendoza-Nieto et al. [21] exhibited that the catalyst NiMoW placed on SBA-15 was more efficient for the HDS of DBT and 4,6-DMDBT than the catalysts NiMo and NiW supported on SBA-15. Mo, CoMo, NiMo, and NiCoMo catalysts using SBA-15 as alternate support have been reported, showing better catalytic activity in the HDS reaction compared to that observed in catalysts supported on alumina [22–25]. This effect is because alumina has some impediments compared to SBA-15, such as low surface area, low pore volume, and higher interaction of the active phase with the support, which causes greater difficulty during catalyst activation, to mention a few. Many studies showed that the catalysts with Co, Ni, and Mo could be more active in the HDS reactions due to the electron density development on the anti-bonding d orbital of Mo in the active phase. These trimetallic catalysts have the advantage of having mixed phases, and their systems can be easily tailored compared to bimetallic and monometallic catalysts [26]. It was shown that the maximum catalytic activity was achieved when the bimetallic catalyst CoMo was promoted with Ni since it enhanced the formation of active sites. However, Severino et al. [27] and Sadeghbeigi [28] culminated the trimetallic catalyst CoNiMo is less effective compared to bimetallic catalysts during the HDS of thiophene and 4,6 DMDBT. Because of this, it is necessary to analyze the negative or positive effect of adding a second promoter, such as nickel, to a system based on transition metal sulfides (MoS2). Motivated by the above, the objective of the present research work was to investigate the effects of different cobalt and nickel precursors on the structural and catalytic properties of transition metal sulfide-based trimetallic catalysts incorporating nickel in small quantities. Hence, more investigation can be centered on this work to progress the execution of the catalysts. Experimental Materials The SBA-15 support was synthesized using the following reagents: pluronic P-123 (poly (ethylene glicol)-blockpoly (propylene glicol)-block-poly (ethylene glicol)), sulfuric acid (95–98%), sodium hydroxide (≥ 98%), and sodium silicate solution, reagent grade. All reagents were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. The precursor compounds used for the preparation of the catalysts were ammonium heptamolybdate tetrahydrate, (NH4)6Mo7O24.4 H2O, cobalt, and nickel acetates tetrahydrate and/or nitrates hexahydrate (≥98%) and dibenzothiophene (98%) for the catalytic reaction were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Catalysts synthesis To synthesize the support, we followed the method described by [29] to obtain mesoporous SBA-15 support. The catalysts were prepared by the incipient impregnation method. The nominal percentage of Mo kept constant (12%). Ni was added in relative atomic percentages (concerning Co) of 5, 10, and 20 atomic% in such a way that the (Co + Ni)/ (Co + Ni + Mo) molar ratio was near 0.3 and the nominal weight between Co and Ni was 3%. In a typical synthesis, the SBA-15 support was impregnated with solutions of ammonium heptamolybdate, cobalt, nickel acetates, and/or nitrates. After impregnation, the materials were dried at 393.15 K for two h before being calcined at 723.15 K for two h. Finally, the solid oxides were sulfided under H2S/H2 gas flow (15% H2S v/v, 40 cm3/min, and heat ramp 283.15 K/min) at 673.15 K for two h to obtain the trimetallic catalysts. The as-formed catalysts were labeled according to the precursor compounds used (CoNixMo-Ac for acetates and CoNixMo-N for nitrates), where x is the percentage of Ni present. Catalyst characterization To study their textural properties, the trimetallic catalysts were characterized before and after sulfidation. Before sulfidation, the catalysts were analyzed by X-ray diffraction to determine the dispersion of the active metals in the oxide state. After sulfidation, X-ray diffraction characterized the materials again to analyze the crystal structures of the sulfide phases. The N2 adsorption-desorption method was used to calculate the surface area, pore volume, and pore diameter of the catalysts. Transmission electron microscopy was used to determine the length and stacking number of the MoS2 slabs presented, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to calculate the quantity of the Mo, Co, Ni, and S species acquired from the decomposition at the core level spectra. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were determined using a PANalytical X'pert MPD diffractometer equipped with a curved graphite monochromator using the Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å), a Ni filter, and an X'Celerator detector. Patterns were acquired in the 5◦–80◦ 2θ range. The surface area and pore volume were calculated using Micromeritics GEMINI 2360 equipment. Before analysis, all the samples were degassed under flowing Ar at 423 K for two h. Surface areas were calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller method, while the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) model was used for pore size determination considering the desorption branch of N2 isotherms. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained using a JEOL JEM-2200FS (200 kV) microscope to get information about 300 slabs of MoS2 and stacking degree. The slab length and stacking degree were calculated using the ImageJ software. Finally, the XPS analyses were performed using a SPECS® spectrometer equipped with a PHOIBOS® 150 WAL hemispherical energy analyzer with an angular resolution lower than 0.5° The XPS apparatus also possesses a μ-FOCUS 500 X-ray monochromator (Al excitation line). The fresh sulfided catalyst samples were transferred to the XPS chamber under an Ar atmosphere without contact with air to evade reoxidation. Binding energies were referenced to the adventitious C 1 s peak (284.8 eV). Background subtraction was performed using a Shirley baseline, while mixed Gaussian/Lorentzian functions were used to fit core-level spectra. Catalytic activity HDS of DBT was performed using a high-pressure Parr reactor with 0.2 g of catalyst, 500 ppm of DBT, and 100 ml of hexadecane. The reactor was first heated at 593.15 K and pressurized to 55 bars with H2. The particle size and agitation were established between 80 and 120 mesh and 700 rpm to prevent diffusion limitations. The initial time was fixed when agitation started at the final temperature and pressure conditions. Samples were taken at 15, 30, 45, 60, 90, 120, 180, 240, and 300 min during the reaction before being analyzed to determine the evolution of the HDS conversion in the function of the reaction. The samples were analyzed on an Agilent Technologies 7890A GC System Gas Chromatograph with a 30 m long HP-5 capillary column with an internal diameter of 0.32 mm, equipped with an Agilent 355 SCD detector type Agilent 355 SCD. The reaction products detected by gas chromatography were biphenyl (BP), cyclohexylbenzene (CHB), dicyclohexyl (DCH), and tetrahydrodibenzothiophene (THDBT). The initial reaction rate and selectivity were obtained as reported by [30]. The catalytic activity was expressed by the initial reaction rate, determined from DBT conversion (XDBT) as a function of time (molDBT transformed per second and gram of catalyst). For each catalyst, the calculated regression coefficient (R2) values ranged from 0.985 to 0.999, and the apparent rate constant standard errors ranged from 3.57 to 3.83%. This characteristic can be utilized to compare the catalytic activity of the synthesized materials because an identical quantity of catalyst was employed in each experiment, and they all had similar metal charges. Results and discussion Characterization at the oxide state X-ray diffraction Fig. 1 (A, B) show the low-angle XRD patterns of the pure SBA-15 support and the catalysts in the oxide state. All materials exhibit three well-defined signals (Miller indexes), d100, d110, and d200, associated with the diffraction peaks of a hexagonal structure with p6mm symmetry. The signal related to the (100), (110), and (200) planes appear at 2θ = 1.03°, 2°, and 2.7° respectively. Fig. 2 (A, B) shows the dispersion of the active phases at a wide angle in the diffraction patterns of the catalysts. The patterns don´t show the presence of Ni and Co oxides. This result indicates a good dispersion of the promoters on the support. However, it can be seen two peaks at 2θ = 26.5° and 28.4° which indicate the presence of the β-NiMoO4 and β-CoMoO4, respectively. In the case of Mo, several signals are observed, which correspond to the orthorhombic phase of MoO3 according to the crystallographic chart JCPDS 35–609. This phase was observed with 12 wt% Mo and contrasts with the report of Huang et al. [31] which states that there is no reflection from crystalline phase MoO3 below 13 wt%. Characterization at the sulfide state N2 physisorption Fig. 3 (A, B) shows the behavior of the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms for SBA-15 and the catalysts supported on this material. The materials present a type IV isotherm characteristic of mesoporous materials according to the IUPAC classification. This proof shows that the addition of Co, Ni, and Mo species does not destroy the mesoporous structure of SBA-15. The hysteresis is of type H1, characteristic of bottleneck-type pores [32] because part of the metallic charge was incorporated at the entrance of the pore, forming this bottleneck. In Fig. 4 (A, B), the BJH pore size distribution was observed for all the materials. In the case of the catalysts CoNixMo-Ac, a bimodal pore size distribution can be seen in the support and in the catalyst CoNi10Mo-Ac. This behavior is attributed to creating small intra-wall mesopores produced for the Pluronic P123 during the filter and calcination process. In the case of the catalysts prepared using cobalt and nickel nitrates, this behavior is not observed, meaning a better preparation of the materials. The textural properties: of specific surface area (SSA), average pore diameter (Dp), and pore volume (Vp) corresponding to the catalysts supported on SBA-15 are presented in Table 1 . The support shows a decrease in surface area after adding Co, Ni, and Mo metals by around 53% (Table 1). However, this is still higher than expected due to the high surface area of the support without the active phase. This may be due to the active phase partially blocking some pores, which agrees with the pore shape obtained from the shape of the adsorption-desorption isotherm hysteresis. Additionally, it is observed that the pore diameter and pore volume of the impregnated catalysts were not significantly affected despite the observed reduction, which corroborates that the active phase partially blocks the pores. X-ray diffraction Fig. 5 (A, B) show the XRD patterns of the trimetallic catalysts supported in SBA-15 in the interval 2θ from 10° to 80 ° In both cases, it could be seen the poorly crystalline phase 2H-MoS2. CoNixMo-Ac catalysts present a more amorphous behavior than the CoNixMo-N catalysts, probably due to the Ni content since as the Ni increases, the peaks tend to be less intense till they disappear (CoNi20Mo-Ac). These catalysts show reflections at 2θ = 28° (004), 33° (100), and 52 ° (105) associated with the hexagonal phase of MoS2. However, the patterns did not present a strong reflection peak in plane 002, attributed to a major layer destacking of the MoS2 [33]. Also, the patterns show a peak at 2θ = 23°, corresponding to the orthorhombic structure of sulfur Fddd. In addition, the patterns revealed peaks related to the presence of the phase Co9S8 (reflection 440) according to the crystalline card 37–1492. This phase appears for the catalysts with 5 and 10 percent. This phase is not visible for the case of the catalyst with 20 percent. This effect could be to the increase of the Ni, which inhibited the formation of this phase. On the other hand, the CoNixMo-N catalysts present peaks that are more defined. It can be observed that the patterns look more like the ones reported in the literature. The four catalysts prepared with nitrates exhibited the typical planes (002), (100), (103), and (110). In addition, the results show that the intensity of the peaks does not change with increasing Ni. This suggests that the increase of Ni does not affect the crystal structures; they keep the same. And finally, we can observe the presence of the orthorhombic structure of sulfur Fddd, like in the case of the catalysts with acetates. Transmission electron microscopy The micrographs of the sulfide catalysts prepared with acetates and nitrates are displayed in Fig. 6 . The micrographs show the characteristic layer-hexagonal crystal structure of MoS2 crystallites (white arrows). The basal plane 002 of the MoS2 crystallite corresponds to the interplanar distance between the slabs, which is 0.61 nm. At these magnifications, it is possible to observe the straight, parallel, well-defined channels characteristic of SBA-15 (orange arrows). The average length (L), average stacking (N), and dispersion of the slabs of the six sulfided catalysts were determined and analyzed for around 300 particles (Table 2 ). The results show that as the Ni increases, the slab length and stacking degree decrease, showing a progressive but moderate increase in the dispersion of the MoS2 slab length and the formation of shorter and less-stacking MoS2 crystallites. Moreover, from the results, the catalysts CoNi20Mo-Ac and CoNi20Mo-Ac present the highest dispersion. The difference in how the active phase precursor interacts with the surface during impregnation and the subsequent activation stage can be used to explain this. Catalytic activity An evolution of the HDS activity with the quantity of nickel present can be seen in the starting reaction rate for the hydrodesulfurization of dibenzothiophene as a function of the Ni concentration (Fig. 7 ). In the case of the CoNi5Mo-Ac, this catalyst presented lower catalytic activity with a value of 32.5 × 10−08 molDBT·gcat −1·s−1. Increasing the amount of Ni (20%), the initial reaction rate increased to a value of 49.5 × 10−08 molDBT·gcat −1·s−1. This is probably related to the fact that Ni is starting to compete with Co for the occupation of the metallic edge planes, causing a positive synergetic effect and forming a CoNiMoS phase affecting the initial reaction rate. Moreover, when the catalysts were prepared using nitrates, a similar result was shown, since as the Ni increased, the initial reaction rate increased for the CoNi10Mo-N catalyst to 38.5 × 10−08 molDBT·gcat −1·s−1 from 36.4×10−08 molDBT·gcat −1·s−1 for the CoNi5Mo-N catalyst. By increasing Ni by 20%, the reaction rate increases, possibly due to a positive synergetic effect between the two promoters. This behavior contrasts the observed where an optimum speed was obtained with less Ni percentage (5%). This means that the type of precursor used has an essential effect on the catalysts since modifying their properties and catalytic activity. It indicates that the materials synthesized with cobalt and nickel acetate precursors can help improve the intrinsic activity of the HDS sites. In all cases, the results reveal comparable HYD/DDS ratios at 20% of conversion (0.1 and 0.08 for CoNi5Mo-Ac and CoNi10-Ac; 0.09 and 0.07 for CoNi5Mo-N and CoNi10Mo-N), with the notable exception of CoNi20Mo-Ac and CoNi20Mo-N, which has an HYD/DDS ratio of 0.11. This suggests that the promoted active sites, are more hydrogenating in nature and can alter the selectivity qualities. XPS analysis of sulfided samples In the general survey, photopeaks related to C, O, Co, Mo, S, and Si atoms can be observed very clearly (not shown here). On the other hand, the peak related to the presence of Ni is not observed due to the low concentration with which the materials were prepared. All spectra were calibrated with the C 1 s photopeak at 284.8 eV. In the initial approach, the S 2p core emission region was acquired to verify that there was no sulfate species at approximately 168 eV [34]. As can be observed in Fig. 8 , no sample presented that peak, confirming that the materials, once sulfated, did not have contact with oxygen from the environment. It is worth mentioning that the only peak observed in this region was at BE of 162.1 eV related to sulfide state species [35]. In the case of O 1 s, C 1 s, and Si 2p, we did not observe significant changes in the corresponding spectra when comparing each other. However, the chemical composition is provided in Table S1 for all the samples analyzed. As an example, we present the deconvolution process performed in the spectra of the highest activity samples from each series for Co 2p3/2 (Fig. 9 A) and Mo 3d (Fig. 9B) core emission line regions. The spectra related to the Co 2p3/2 and those of Mo 3d for the remaining samples are presented in the supplementary information as Figure S1 and S2, respectively, for the sake of clarity and shorten the extension of this work. In Fig. 9A is possible to observe that three species of Co were used to fit the spectrum with their respective satellites successfully. At photopeak centered at BE of 777.7 eV was assigned the CoSx species, while the peak at 779.1 is related to the CoMoS nonstoichiometric phase [36]. Lastly, the peak assigned to the CoOx species was fixed at 780.6 eV. Each satellite was set at 4.4 eV of the main related specie. It is worth noticing that CoSx and CoOx species in both samples appear at the same BE. However, the CoMoS phase shifted slightly to lower BE from 779.1 eV in the CoNi20Mo-Ac sample to 778.8 eV in the CoNi20Mo-N sample. In the Mo 3d core emission line region for sulfided samples, three Mo species, and one or two S 2 s species appear. In the case of Mo species (see Fig. 9B), the peaks related to Mo6+, Mo5+, and Mo4+ are typically reported at BE of 232.5 eV, 230.2 eV, and 229.3 eV for the main peak Mo 3d3/2 respectively [37]. The peaks of the Mo 3d1/2 were fixed with a delta of 3.13 eV, as the literature indicates [38]. The sulfur environment detected in this region corresponds to S 2 s in S2− and S2 2− species at 226.4 eV and 227.4 eV, respectively. In this case of the Mo 3d core line, it was also observed a slight shift to lower BE of the CoNi20Mo-N concerning the CoNi20Mo-Ac of around 0.43 eV, although the same species were used to fit both spectra. The semiquantitative XPS analysis in Table S1 demonstrated that the composition is very similar among materials. It is worth mentioning that the presence of Ni was indeed detected in the respective high-resolution window, although the species in the sample are not possible to identify through the deconvolution process due to the poor counts obtained. Instead, in Table 3 , we present the semiquantitative analysis obtained from the deconvolution process performed in the high-resolution windows for the Co 2p3/2 and Mo 3d with the species indicated before using the previously indicated approach [39]. The careful deconvolution process indicated that in CoNixMo-Ac samples, the Mo+6 and Mo+5 species decreased with the increase in Ni content, while Mo+4 species increased from 64% to 72.3% in the CoNi5Mo-Ac and CoNi20Mo-Ac samples respectively. In the CoNixMo-N series, the trend for the Mo+6 resulted in inverse respect to the CoNixMo-Ac samples. In the case of Mo+5 species, it was observed that the de% decreased similarly to the CoNixMo-Ac samples. The Mo+4 appeared almost with the same values with slight differences that could be within the experimental incertitude. In the case of Co species, the behavior observed confirm that CoOx species decreased with the increase in Ni content from 30.9% in the CoNi5Mo-Ac sample to 22.8% in the CoNi20Mo-Ac sample. The CoMoS phase, on the other hand, increased from 58.9% to 65.1% in the CoNi5Mo-Ac sample to the CoNi20Mo-Ac sample, respectively. In the case of CoSx species, the values obtained were around 11.6% on average in the CoNixMo-Ac series. The variations observed in the CoNixMo-N series in the Co 2p region were less drastic, and the values almost remained constant in the three materials of this series. For example, in the CoMoS phase, the values obtained were 57.2%, 59.8 and 60.2% for the CoNi5Mo-N, CoNi10Mo-N, and CoNi20Mo-N, respectively. To end the study of the catalytic activity of the trimetallic catalysts and given that the dispersion of the slabs of MoS2 changes when nickel increases, the HDS result was also studied by the determination of the initial intrinsic rate (Ri, molec. Mo at−1·s−1) and the turnover frequency (TOF, h−1). In this regard, calculating the turnover frequency (TOF) values enables the evaluation of the relative intrinsic activities of the prior catalysts and the improvement in catalytic efficiency brought about by adding nickel to cobalt-promoted MoS2 catalysts. The Ri and TOF values were obtained using the equation reported by [39] as follows: R i = R s · N d a t where Rs is the initial reaction rate (molDBT·gcat−1·s−1), dat is the atomic density of Mo atoms per g, and N is the Avogadro number. T O F ( h − 1 ) = R s · N [ M o e I V ] where Rs is the initial reaction rate (molDBT·gcat·s−1), N is the Avogadro number, and [MoIV e] is the number of MoIV edge sites per g obtained by a combination of the nominal percentage of Mo (12%) and XPS results. The results obtained from the calculations of the Ri and TOF are shown in Table 4 . The results showed how the HDS catalysts' inherent activity is increased by the controlled addition of Ni, even in minimal concentration. Since the Co content is similar in both catalyst series, the improved catalytic activity results from Ni incorporation into the M-edge sites of the MoS2 slabs at sites not occupied by Co atoms, possibly leading to NiMoS sites' formation. On the other hand, because the presence of Ni could not be detected during the XPS analysis, the NiMoS phase was not quantified. However, the authors believe that it does form but to a lesser extent. General discussion The effect of the precursor compounds in the synthesis of the catalyst is one of the essential steps since they need to be transformed entirely into oxide particles and not leave compounds that can alter the properties of the desired materials. Usually, the precursor compounds more frequently used to prepare supported catalysts in an oxide state for hydrodesulfurization are based on nitrates like Ni and Co due to their low-cost, high solubility, and the fact that they can be decomposed at an average low temperature. On the other hand, during the decomposition of the precursors, they can produce NOx, and the dispersion of the active species could be low. On the other hand, if the precursor compound is still hydrosoluble and reasonably priced, choosing counterions other than nitrates is an alternative. These specifications can be met using metal acetates. They dissolve more slowly than nitrates do. Additionally, they break down into CO2 and water. The synthesized catalysts showed that Ni upgrading and using acetates or nitrates influenced their catalytic and structural properties. Through the X-ray diffraction analysis of the catalysts in the oxide state at low and wide angles, the absence of the CoO and NiO phases was confirmed. However, the presence of the β-NiMoO4 and β-CoMoO4 phases was observed, indicating that Ni and Co interact with Mo and help in its redispersion. Regarding Mo, this atom was found in the form of the MoO3 crystalline phase in large clusters, probably due to a low metal-support interaction. The XRD analysis in the sulfide state indicates the presence of the Co9S8 phase, indicating the segregation of the cobalt species during the catalytic test. In the sulfide state, various peaks related to the MoS2, S8, and the Co9S8 phases were observed. However, the peak corresponding to plane 002 was not found in any of the catalysts, indicating a destacking of the MoS2 slabs. The TEM statistical results confirmed an increase in the length and dispersion of the slabs, as well as a decrease in the stacking number with the addition of Ni content. The length decrease in Table 2 could be directly related to the catalytic activity variations. The results of the hydrodesulfurization of dibenzothiophene confirmed such an assumption since increasing the amount of Ni increased the initial reaction rate almost linearly, obtaining an optimal catalyst with 20% of Ni replacing cobalt in the catalyst. This behavior was observed in both systems, although the Ni content effect was more evident in the samples synthesized with Ni acetate precursors. This was also attributed to the fact that Co and Ni had a synergistic effect when decorating the MoS2 slabs. In this direction, the XPS analysis of the sulfided state samples indicates that the CoMoS phase increase with the increase in Ni content. The same behavior was observed for the Mo sulfidation degree, indicating that the presence of Ni is beneficial for the dispersion and% of active phase formation. It is worth mentioning at this time that due to the low amount of Ni in the samples, the signal corresponding to the electrons arising from the Ni 2p was barely observed, making it impossible to quantify the nickel species present on the surface of the samples. From the results obtained from the comparative study, it was concluded that even though the general composition did not vary much in the six catalysts, the species present in each of the samples showed a good correlation between the catalytic activity and the formation of the nonstoichiometric CoMoS phase, as can be seen in Fig. 10 . Conclusion The current research studied the influence of the use of two types of salts precursor on the structural and catalytic properties of trimetallic catalysts by adding Ni in small amounts. The salt precursors used were cobalt and nickel acetates and nitrates due to their low-cost, high-water solubility, and low decomposition at moderate temperatures. The resultant catalysts were studied in both the oxide and sulfide phases, demonstrating that the ideal preparation conditions were attained when roughly 20% of nickel was added. This effect is attributed to the fact that the metal edge of MoS2 is in contact with Ni promoter atoms, and Mo atoms are more readily available at the MoS2 slab margins when Ni concentration rises and start to cover them, forcing the slabs to contract and expose more active sites and resulting in a rise in hydrodesulfurization activity. coredata.dc:description: In the present research project, it was studied in detail how the incorporation of different precursor compounds and the supplementary addition of amounts of nickel in the MoS2 slabs can influence the structural and catalytic properties of trimetallic CoNiMo catalysts supported on SBA-15 mesoporous support with precise control of the amount and nature of the promoters. The catalysts were prepared by the incipient impregnation method using ammonium heptamolybdate and cobalt and nickel acetate, and nitrate as precursors adding nickel in molar amounts (5, 10, and 20%) of the cobalt atomic loading. Adding the Ni in small amounts allows us to keep the (Co + Ni)/(Co+Ni+Mo) molar ratio near 0.3. The catalysts formed were labeled according to the precursor compounds used (CoNixMo-Ac for acetates and CoNixMo-N for nitrates), where x is the percentage of nickel. Catalysts were then characterized by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, X-ray diffraction, high-resolution transmission electron microscopy, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. Catalysts were tested in the HDS of dibenzothiophene (DBT). Results show a significant impact of adding small amounts of nickel and the type of precursor compounds used for the CoNiMo trimetallic catalysts on the final HDS activity. In the case of the catalysts prepared with cobalt and nickel acetates, it was observed that the initial reaction rate values increased as the amount of Ni increased, being the CoNi5Mo-Ac, the catalyst with the lower catalytic activity. Increasing the amount of Ni causes an increase in the HDS of DBT. In the case of the catalysts prepared with nitrates, it could be observed a similar effect. The catalyst with the higher catalytic activity in both series was the CoNi20Mo-Ac. These results agree with the TEM analysis in which a decrease in the slab length of the MoS2 could be regarded as the de Ni amount increase. This means that the type of precursor used has an essential effect on the catalysts since modify their properties and catalytic activity and suggests that the materials synthesized with acetate precursors can help to improve the intrinsic activity of the HDS sites.
coredata.dc:title: Influence of precursor compounds on the structural and catalytic properties of CoNiMo/SBA-15 catalysts used in the hydrodesulfurization of dibenzothiophene
